message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: draft Translator's Preface now or after?">
The author asks: should the translator write a draft of the Translator's Preface NOW (before full translation begins) to capture all the decisions while they're fresh — with the understanding it will be revised after translation is complete? Or should we wait until after?

Reply "NOW" or "AFTER" with a brief reason.
</teammate-message>

input.content: NOW — The Translation Dictionary, all 7 resolved Q-files, 9 expert reports, and the editorial decisions (德 split convention, -scape system, 境界 footnote placement, intoxicated/lucid pair, etc.) are all live in context right now. If we wait until after the full translation, we will have to reconstruct the reasoning behind dozens of decisions from files rather than from active memory. A draft now captures the "why" behind each choice while the deliberative process is fresh. It also gives the translator a reference document to consult during translation — ensuring the Preface and the translation stay aligned rather than diverging. The draft will certainly need revision after translation (new issues will emerge, phrasing will need to match what actually appears on the page), but the structural backbone — the explanation of 境/Jing, the 鱼/渔 metaphor, the 德 split, the bilingual nature, the "essays as experiments" warning — is stable now and will not change.
input.summary: NOW — decisions fresh, captures reasoning, guides translation
